EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Pursuant to the requirements of Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations Part 68.1 through 68.220 and Chapter 6.95, Article 2 of the California Health & Safety Code ?25531 through ?25543.3, this federal Risk Management Plan (RMP) is implemented as the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.

The scope of this RMP is based on the guidance of the Certified Unified Program Agency (CUPA), the City of Oxnard Fire Department, to ensure that all contemporary issues are resolved and to incorporate state requirements. With input from the CUPA, the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) ammonia storage and handling system has been identified as the only process at the facility which triggers the CalARP RMP requirements. This process was determined to be covered by Prevention Program 2 requirements.

On March 31, 2004, the amendment to the Chemical Accident Prevention Rule (Risk Management Program) under the Clean Air Act Section 112 (r) (7) was signed. The amendment:



* Requires a correction to reportable information on chemical accidents be added to the RMP within six (6) months of the date of the accident;

* Requires that changes to emergency contact information be corrected within one (1) month;

* Removes the requirement to include a brief description of the off-site consequence analysis (OCA) in the RMP executive summary; and

* Adds three (3) RMP data elements.

EPA also amended the RMP*Submit format to expand the list of possible accident causes to include uncontrolled chemical reactions.  This amendment became effective on April 9, 2004 when it was published in the Federal Register.  In April 2008 EPA began work on RMP*eSUBMIT software which will replace RMP*Submit. RMP*eSUBMIT was released March 13, 2009. On that date additional modifications to the RMP regulation became effective, including changes to the accidental release 5-year recordkeeping and reporting requirements.

1.1 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Respons

e Policies

It is the policy of RRI Energy, Inc. (RRI) that its employees, environment, property, and the general public be protected from any harm that may occur as a result of its operations.  To achieve this end, RRI strives to operate its facilities in compliance with applicable federal, state, and local safety, health, and environmental regulations.  

RRI implements its emergency response policies to comply with the overall corporate policy of providing its workers with a safe workplace and of minimizing risk to the public. The safety of emergency and non-affected personnel is the highest priority; therefore, all procedures must be implemented in the appropriate manner (e.g., safely executed rescue and medical activities).  Protection of the environment is also a high priority.  Once the issues of life, safety, and the environment are addressed, the secondary issues of property conservation and business recovery may be considered.

1.2 Facility Description

The Ormond Beach Generating Station (Facility ID 1000 0009 5327) is located at 6635 South Edison Drive in Oxnard, California at the southern margin of the Oxnard Plain adjacent to the Pacific Ocean and approximately 60 miles west northwest of Los Angeles, California (34? 7? 44? north, 119? 10? 4? west).  The elevation of the facility is approximately 15 feet above sea level.  The nearest earthquake fault zones are the Malibu Coast-Santa Monica-Hollywood-Raymond Fault Zone 9 miles southeast of the site; the Oak Ridge Fault 9 miles north of the site; and the Ventura Fault 11 miles north of the site.

The station is located in a light to heavy industrial zone. The main area covers approximately 53 acres and is bounded by Edison Drive on the north and by the Pacific Ocean on the south. A Ventura County Railway spur (Union Pacific Railroad) runs into the property for transporting heavy equipment. This railroad is shared with other industrial facilities in the area. A vicinity and location map is contained in App

endix A.

The Ormond Beach Generating Station consists of two gas-fired boilers and associated steam-driven turbine units, each rated at 750 MW (7400 MMBtu/hr) and two 275 MMBtu/hr auxiliary boilers used for starting the main units. Main Units 1 and 2 are each equipped with SCR for the control of oxides of nitrogen (NOx) emissions. Aqueous ammonia is also used in the station water treatment system for pH control, and in the demineralizer system for the regeneration of anion and cation exchange resins.

The regulated substance used at the facility above California?s threshold quantity (TQ) is aqueous ammonia (ammonium hydroxide, 29% by weight).  All other regulated substances onsite are in quantities below applicable thresholds.





1.2.1 Selective Catalytic Reduction

Aqueous ammonia (CAS 1336-21-6), 29% concentration by weight, with a vapor pressure of 9.1 psig at 60?F is used in the SCR system to control NOx emissions from two 7400 MMBtu/hr steam boilers (Units 1 and 2) as Best Available Control Technology (BACT). The SCR system reduces NOx emissions by injecting ammonia into the boiler exhaust gas stream upstream of a catalyst matrix. Ammonia, NOx, and oxygen react on the surface of the catalyst to form nitrogen and water. The low temperature catalyst is comprised of vanadium pentoxide (V2O5) on a ceramic substrate and operates within a normal temperature range of 600?F to 750?F. A process flow diagram is contained in Appendix B. 

1.2.2 Regulated Substances

Aqueous ammonia is a toxic substance above the federal RMP and CalARP thresholds (19 CCR ?2770.5, Tables 1 and 3, respectively).  No regulated flammable substances are present at the facility in excess of the threshold quantities under the regulation. All quantities of other materials are also below applicable thresholds.

* Aqueous ammonia, 29% by weight, 40,0000 gallons (max), 87,000 pounds (max) as NH3

Vanadium pentoxide (trade name VNX) is the active SCR catalyst material. VNX is a solid deposited on a ceramic honeycomb material (less than 5% in matrix), the design of which promotes interaction with the exhaust gas stream within the SCR.  As such, VNX remains within the SCR and is not released to the atmosphere. This substance, therefore, meets the definition of an article (?2735.3) and is therefore exempted from the requirements of the CalARP program as per ?2770.2(b)(3).  VNX is not federally listed under 40 CFR 68 Appendix A.

1.3 Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program

The Ormond Beach Generating Station uses aqueous ammonia in the SCR NOX reduction system.  Aqueous ammonia is a regulated substance and is present at the facility above the federal RMP and CalARP TQ. Therefore, RRI is subject to the RMP and CalARP requirements. The facility is coded:



* North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS) as 221112

* Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) 4911

In accordance with the CalARP regulations and with the guidance of the Oxnard Fire Department as CUPA, it has been determined that the SCR system falls under the CalARP Prevention Program 2 requirement.

Compliance with the CalARP comprehensive program validates the integrity of the processes which handle flammable or toxic materials.  The objectiv

e of the regulation is to prevent accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.   To control these types of hazards, RRI has developed the necessary expertise, experience, judgment and proactive initiative within their workforce to properly implement and maintain an effective prevention program. Through compliance with the regulations, standards, and with CUPA guidance, the RRI facility has implemented the requirements of the Prevention Program 2. 

1.3.1 Prevention Program 2 Elements

An effective program requires a systematic approach to evaluating the whole chemical process. Using this approach the following components were considered in the evaluation in accordance with Title 40 CFR 68.48 through 68.60 (Subpart C) and Title 19 CCR ?2745.6.  Program 2 includes all four (4) Program 1 elements and seven (7) additional elements:











Program 1 Elements (40 CFR 68.12 & 68.15)



* 5-Year Accident History

* Hazard Assessment (Offsite Consequence Analysis)

* Emergency Response Program

* Management System



Additional Program 2 Elements (40 CFR 68 Subpart C)



* Safety Information

* Hazard Review

* Operating Procedures

* Employee Training

* Maintenance Procedures

* Compliance Audits

* Incident Investigation

The various lines of defense that have been incorporated into the design and operation of the process to prevent or mitigate the release of hazardous chemicals have been evaluated and strengthened to assure their effectiveness at each level.  RRI uses the proactive identification, evaluation and mitigation for prevention of chemical releases that could occur as a result of failures in process, procedures or equipment. 

1.3.2 Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

In addition to implementation of the CalARP Prevention Program 2 elements, RRI has implemented specific safety features for the prevention, detection and control of releases of regulated (and other) substances at the RRI Facility.  The following are some of the control and detection equipment l

ocated in and around the facility to minimize the risk of an accident involving hazardous materials:



* Pressure relief and safety valves

* High level alarms and shutoffs

* Secondary tank containment (55,000 gallons) 

* Emergency control stations (control room)

* Ammonia gas detector system

* Fail-safe and interlock process controls (automatic)

* Emergency shutdown systems (ESD)



1.4 Five-Year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases from the aqueous ammonia storage and handling system at the Ormond Beach Generating Station in the past five years that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage  (Statute:  40 CFR 68.42).

1.5 Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) Summary

Per April 9, 2004 amendments to the Chemical Accident Prevention rule (69 FR 18819), description of OCA is no longer required in the executive summary. 

1.6 Emergency Response Program Summary

RRI has developed written emergency response procedures to address all elements that may be encountered during planning, response or follow-up of an emergency at the facility.  Application of the emergency response procedures ensures compliance with CalOSHA Title 8 ?3220 (Emergency Action Plan) and OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.38 (Emergency Action Plans or EAP).  The basic concept of RRI?s emergency procedures is to provide a comprehensive approach for managing emergencies.  The four elements of this approach are prevention, preparedness, response, and recovery.

RRI?s emergency procedures serve as a guide for emergency control staff, company personnel, emergency assistance groups and law enforcement agencies that may be called upon to participate in controlling an emergency within the facility and surrounding areas. These procedures include employee notification of emergencies and evacuation procedures for all emergency situations.  

Pursuant to CU

PA requirements (per 40 CFR 68.12 and 19 CCR ?2745.8) emergency procedures are in place in the event of a release of a regulated substance (aqueous ammonia).  Emergency response training is conducted annually.  The most recent emergency response classroom training was in February 21, 2008. The last Emergency Response drill, a simulated ammonia release event, was conducted on August 7, 2008. A CUPA inspection was conducted on May 13, 2008. A Fire Department inspection followed on November 10, 2008.







The Ormond Beach Generating Station?s emergency response plan includes the following core elements:



* Specific actions to be taken in response to an accidental release of aqueous ammonia

* Procedures to notify local and public agencies including the Oxnard Fire Department, the California Office of Emergency Services, and the National Response Center as necessary

* Information regarding the training of employees 

* A list of other federal and State requirements to which the facility is subject

1.7 Management System Summary

The management system oversees the implementation of the RMP elements in order to manage the risk of a chemical release at this facility.  Pursuant to Title 19 CCR ?2735.6, a program management system has been established to oversee the implementation of the RMP elements.  Management system components for this facility include:



* Identification of the qualified person/position with responsibility for coordinating the RMP

* Organizational chart showing the positions with tasks involving the aqueous ammonia storage and handling system

* Roles and responsibilities of positions at the facility

1.8 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

No action items were identified during the Hazard Review ?what-if? scenarios analysis. RRI enforces continuous improvements to safety and health and tracks training to ensure commitment to safe working practices and the protection of the employees and the environment.  RRI will work closely with the CUPA to con

tinue to ensure that all requirements are addressed.
